ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK
  TAR: OTH 38588 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
 
 
FOR 
 
 
SUPPORTING THE ACHIEVEMENT OF THE  
MILLENNIUM DEVELOPMENT GOALS IN THE ASIA-PACIFIC REGION 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
November 2004

  DMC  –  developing member country 
  HIV/AIDS  –  human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency 
syndrome

NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by S. Chatterjee.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  United  Nations  Economic  and  Social  Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific 
(UNESCAP) and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) jointly produced the first 
Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDG)  Report  in  2003,  which  provided  inputs  to  the  UN 
Secretary General’s Report to the UN General Assembly on progress on the MDGs worldwide. 
The Report (referred to as MDG Report I) served more than just that purpose. It enabled 
valuable stocktaking on the status of the achievement of MDGs in the region, and highlighted 
the significant distance that many countries were from achieving the MDGs and the relevant 
constraints and issues. MDG Report I has received considerable attention in the region. The 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) was not formally associated with MDG Report I, although ADB  
was invited and  participated in the advisory committee, it  provided no funding support for 
preparing the Report. 
 
2.  The second and third MDG reports (MDG reports II and III), scheduled for 2005 and 
2007, respectively, are to  be incorporated  into  the  UN Secretary General’s reports to the 
General Assembly for those years. Both UNESCAP and UNDP felt that ADB’s participation in 
the project would greatly enhance the quality of MDG reports II and III and their usefulness in 
furthering the MDG agenda in the region. A formal request for ADB to participate in the project 
was  made  in  January  2004,  and  ADB  has  formally  agreed  to  participate  in  the  tripartite 
enterprise. ADB held several rounds of discussion with UNESCAP and UNDP staff in Bangkok 
and at ADB headquarters.  The technical assistance (TA) framework (Appendix 1) summarizes 
the main aspects of the TA.    
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  On 2 July 2004, the Board approved the Review of the Poverty Reduction Strategy 
(PRS). The review recommends that ADB adopt a comprehensive monitoring and evaluation 
framework for assessing progress in implementing the enhanced PRS. It was recommended 
that the  overall impact of  ADB’s implementation of the PRS be gauged on the basis of the 
achievement of the MDGs. Given this mandate, there is need to emphasize the quality of 
reporting on MDGs and the strategies for achieving them.  
 
4.  The data and reports on MDGs are usually prepared by or in collaboration with the UN 
system. Reporting on MDGs in the Asia-Pacific region began comprehensively through  MDG 
Report I, which provided an authoritative basis for assessing MDG achievements in the region. 
However, given the magnitude of the tasks, UNESCAP and UNDP alone can neither improve 
the quality of the reporting nor address all the  priority issues. The MDG I Report  initiated a 
comprehensive assessment of the status of MDG attainment, including the MDGs that were at 
risk of nonachievement in the region and the binding constraints.   
 
5.  MDG reports II and III need to go beyond, be of practical relevance to policy practitioners 
in the region, and provide information and guidance on how to attain the targets by 2015. Given 
the immense tasks ahead, there is a need for prioritizing activities.  Some areas have been 
identified for  greater emphasis and  priority action jointly by ADB, UNESCAP, and UNDP in 
consultation with other UN agencies (paras. 6-10).

2  
6.  Improving Data Quality. There are severe gaps in data coverage relating to MDGs, 
weaknesses on the comparability of data across countries,  discrepancies between officially 
reported numbers and those estimated by independent surveys, and, consequently, problems in 
using data for making assessments and projections. This is a medium-term issue that involves 
improving data collection capacity, and efforts to improve techniques  to ensure accuracy of 
estimates. 
 
7.  Country Coverage—Countries at Risk and Central Asia. Several countries—mainly 
the least developed in the Asia-Pacific region—are unlikely to meet the MDG targets, given the 
constraints in resources, institutions, and capacities. There are also subnational areas in many 
countries that are similarly at risk of not attaining the MDGs. To better assist them, a special 
effort to identify these countries and subnational areas and their constraints is necessary. The 
MDG I Report did not adequately address the issues of the Central Asian countries. Issues 
relating to these countries need to be included in future reports.   
 
8.  Thematic Emphasis. Resources and institutional capacity appear to be general binding 
constraints to MDG attainment in the region. The UN is doing considerable work at the global 
level on the resources issue.2 On the other hand, institutional constraints are  increasingly 
becoming critical. There is a need to focus on institutions that can be changed in the medium 
term (by changes in public policy).  
 
9.  Special Issues. Various special issues concerning the MDGs may need particular 
attention. They include the following:  
 
(i)  Hunger and  malnutrition. Although income poverty appears to be declining, 
there are concerns that nutritional levels are stagnant in many cases. Several 
international  initiatives  are  being  taken  including  the  UN  meeting  convened 
recently by the President of Brazil to discuss ways of eradicating hunger.   
 
(ii)  HIV/AIDS.3 The impact of HIV/AIDS on economic development and poverty in 
the region needs to be highlighted and strategies developed for controlling the 
disease.   
 
(iii)  Rural  poverty.  As  most  of  the  region’s  population  still  live  in  the  poor 
underserviced rural areas, rural development and poverty reduction may need 
special attention. The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO)  is stressing this 
factor.   
 
(iv)  Microinitiatives.  Small  community-led  and  local  initiatives  that  have  been 
successful in MDG areas need to be highlighted or upscaled.  
 
10.  Dissemination.  It  has  been  stressed  that  mere  publication  of  reports  will  not  be 
sufficient if the information and issues highlighted are not used by policy makers in the region, 
aid  sources  and  other  stakeholders.  In  view  of  this,  reports  should  be  prepared  with 
dissemination in mind. An effective program of dissemination should be built into the process. 
UNESCAP  is  developing  a  detailed  dissemination  plan  that  includes  preparation  of 
dissemination material; policy dialogue with authorities and discussions with stakeholders at the

country  level  with  the  help  of  ADB  resident  missions  and  UNDP  country  offices;  and 
dissemination by web-sites.   
 
11.  The above issues need to be taken care of through the reports and their dissemination.  
As MDG reports II and  III will have to be succinct (covering no more than 120 pages each), 
other important issues may be covered through an MDG technical paper series.    
 
12.  Given the need to raise awareness, initiate  policy, investment and capacity building 
actions at the developing member country (DMC) level, particularly for DMCs that are at risk of 
not meeting the MDG targets, this TA will  make a strong contribution toward achieving the 
MDGs in the region.  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
13.  The TA’s main goal is  to assist in achieving the MDGs, particularly in countries of the 
Asia-Pacific region that are currently at risk of not achieving the MDGs and where special efforts 
are necessary. It is envisaged that MDG reports II and III, and the background and supporting 
technical papers will raise awareness, lead to improved policies and institutions, and generate 
increased resources and capacities for attaining the MDGs.  
 
14.  The  main  outputs  of  the  TA  are  (i)  MDG  report  II  (scheduled  for  completion by 
September 2005); (ii) MDG report III (scheduled for 2007); (iii) background and supporting 
technical papers; and (iv) dissemination of these reports and papers to appropriate audiences in 
DMCs so that greater awareness is created, and necessary action initiated by governments and 
all stakeholders for MDG attainment.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  ADB, UNESCAP, and UNDP will closely monitor the outputs and outcomes (paras. 19-
20). The reports will be prepared mainly by staff and consultants of the three organizations and 
the wider UN system.  Dissemination of the document and policy dialogue will be coordinated 
through the ADB resident missions and UN country offices, and an effective dissemination plan 
will be developed for this purpose. High-quality output will be ensured through close supervision 
of report preparation at every stage. This will help reduce the risk of mediocrity of outputs.   
 
16.  It is envisaged that MDG report II will tentatively cover the following areas (although a 
final outline will be drawn up only after the steering committee finalizes the matter):  
(i)  Provide an overview of achievements in the Asia-Pacific region and identify 
countries for which special efforts are required and the main constraints in such 
“high risk” countries in meeting the MDG targets. 
(ii)  Build a case for greater mobilization of financial resources to help DMCs achieve 
MDGs. 
(iii)  Collate and coalesce knowledge outputs of different UN agencies focusing on the 
MDGs through a series of technical and background papers. 
(iv)  Showcase selected knowledge products of ADB in which the institution has made 
distinctive contributions, e.g., regional cooperation, gender and development, 
poverty research, water management, rural infrastructure, and good governance,

4  
(v)  Focus on some selected thematic or special issues (paras. 8-9). 
 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA, which includes supporting the preparation of both  MDG reports II and III and 
their dissemination, will cost around $4 million. UNESCAP and UNDP are allocating $1.5 million 
each. A total of $1.0 million (spread over 3 TA phases of $350,000 for phase 1 and $325,000 for 
each of phases 2 and 3) is proposed from ADB. Part of the ADB contribution would be given to 
UNESCAP for their implementation of the project. ADB will implement several activities directly, 
including,  contributions  to  chapters  of  the  main  report,  the  technical  paper  series,  and 
dissemination activities. The three organizations are working out the details.  
 
18.  The present proposal is for phase 1 with a total cost of $1.4 million, of which ADB would 
fund  $350,000  (of  which  an  amount  of  $200,000  will  be  given  to  UNESCAP  for  their 
implementation of the project) and a total of  $1.05 million would be funded by UNESCAP and 
UNDP. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The detailed 
cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.    
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The TA is an important collaborative exercise among ADB, UNDP, and  UNESCAP, 
which have all given their financial and staff resource commitments to ensure quality outputs. A 
formal cooperation arrangement will be entered into with UNESCAP and UNDP defining the 
roles and responsibilities of the partner agencies to ensure smooth implementation of the 
project. ADB will be the Executive Agency for the TA to be implemented by RSDD/RSPR, which 
will coordinate an interdepartmental effort for the purpose. UNESCAP will be mainly responsible 
for report preparation, although inputs from ADB and UNDP will also play a major role. A 
dissemination plan will be drawn up involving close coordination among ADB resident missions 
and UNDP country offices.  
 
20.  The first draft of the main MDG report II is expected by April 2005. A high-level steering 
committee is proposed comprising  the ADB Vice President for Knowledge Management and 
Sustainable Development, UNESCAP Executive Secretary, and UNDP Assistant Administrator 
for East Asia and the Pacific.  In  addition,  there  will  be  an advisory panel on the  reports 
comprising regional experts on MDGs. A working group consisting of representatives at the staff 
level from the three organizations will coordinate the preparation and ensure the quality of MDG 
reports II and III.  
 
21.  The phase I TA will engage 12 person-months of consulting services (6 person-months 
international, and 6 domestic) for the TA activities directly undertaken by ADB. The consultants 
to be  hired by ADB  will be  development specialists with experience in the area of MDGs 
(Appendix 3). The consultants will be engaged individually in accordance with the Guidelines on 
the  Use  of  Consultants  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  and  Its  Borrowers  and  other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. 
 
22.  The TA is phase I of a cluster TA that will run for 4 years altogether in three phases of 15 
months each. The main purpose of phase 1 will be to support the preparation of MDG report II 
and its dissemination. Phase I will run from 1 October 2004 until the end of 2005 (15 months).  It 
is currently envisaged that Phase 2 will focus on dissemination activities of MDG report II, 
preparation of technical background papers, and preparatory activities for MDG report III. Phase

5
3 will focus mainly on MDG report III and its dissemination.  However, the content of the later 
phases  will  be  determined  based  on  the  needs  and  priorities  indicated  by  the  steering 
committee.      
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved  the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $350,000 on a grant basis for 
Supporting the Achievement of the Millennium Development Goals in the Asia-Pacific Region, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance will engage 12 person-months of consulting services (6 person-
months international, and 6 domestic) for the TA activities directly undertaken by ADB.  
 
1.  MDG Specialist (international, 6 person-months) 
 
2.  The Millennium Development Goal (MDG) specialist will be an expert on development, 
particularly poverty reduction and  MDGs, have  considerable  experience  working  on  MDG-
related issues and, have contributed to international journals in the areas.  The task will be to 
contribute a chapter  on strategies to achieve MDGs in countries currently considered at risk in 
MDG report II and to support the work of Poverty Reduction and Social Development Division 
(RSPR) in providing resources toward the MDG report II. Specifically this work will involve the 
following: 
(i)  In close coordination with United Nations Economic and Social Commission for 
Asia  and  the  Pacific  (UNESCAP),  United  Nations  Development  Programme 
(UNDP), and Asian Development Bank (ADB) staff, prepare a chapter of about 
15 pages long (with additional pages for appendixes) that broadly describes the 
current situation with respect to the MDG targets in specific countries, makes a 
thorough analysis of constraints, and provides clear recommendations on how to 
overcome them.    
(ii)  Review concept notes, draft chapters, and technical papers prepared in support 
of MDG report II and give comprehensive comments to improve the quality of the 
final document. 
(iii)  Participate in workshops and seminars undertaken as part of the MDG report II 
exercise and act as resource person if necessary. 
 
2.  MDG Expert (domestic, 6 person-months) 
3.  The MDG expert will have professional experience in development particularly poverty 
reduction and MDGs, have considerable experience with working on MDG-related issues, and 
have written contributions in the areas in internationally reputed publications. The task of the 
expert will be to support the work of the international consultant in each of the areas described 
below: 
(i)  In close coordination with UNESCAP, UNDP, and ADB staff, prepare a chapter 
of about 15 pages  long (with additional pages for appendixes)  that broadly 
describes  the  current  situation  with  respect  to  the  MDG  targets  in  specific 
countries,  makes  a  thorough  analysis  of  constraints,  and  provides  clear 
recommendations on how to overcome them.    
(ii)  Review concept notes, draft chapters and technical papers prepared in support 
of MDG report II and give comprehensive comments to improve the quality of the 
final document. 
(iii)  Participate in workshops and seminars undertaken as part of the MDG report II 
exercise and act as resource person if necessary.
